item.title: Theory: Linear Programming Formulation and Constrained MDPs
item.description: Note: Throughout this section, we assume that \(\ALPHABET S\) and \(\ALPHABET A\) are finite and \(|\ALPHABET S|= n\) and \(|\ALPHABET A| = m\). We know that if \(V \le \mathcal B V\) then \(V \le V^* = \mathcal B V^*\). Thus, \(V^*\) is the “largest” \(V\) that satisfies the constraint \(V \le \mathcal B V\). This constraint can be written as a finite system of linear equations: \[\begin{equation} \label{eq:constaints} V(s) \le c(s,a) + γ\sum_{z \in \ALPHABET S} P(z|s,a) V(z), \qquad s \in \ALPHABET S, a \in \ALPHABET A.
